question_text: What is meant by the following terms? Give an example of the reaction in each case: (i) Cyanohydrin (ii) Acetal (iii) Semicarbazone (iv) Aldol (v) Hemiacetal (vi) Oxime (vii) Ketal (viii) Imine (ix) 2,4-DNP-derivative (x) Schiff's base
correct_answer: A complete answer should define each derivative: For example, a cyanohydrin is a compound having the –C(OH)(CN) group formed by the addition of HCN to a carbonyl compound; an acetal is formed when an aldehyde reacts with two equivalents of an alcohol (usually under acid catalysis) forming R–CH(OR')2; a semicarbazone is formed by the reaction of a carbonyl compound with semicarbazide (H2N–NH–CO–NH2); an aldol is the β-hydroxy aldehyde or ketone obtained in an aldol reaction; a hemiacetal is the intermediate resulting from addition of one equivalent of alcohol to an aldehyde; an oxime is produced when hydroxylamine (NH2OH) reacts with a carbonyl group; a ketal is the acetal derivative of a ketone; an imine (Schiff's base) is formed by the condensation of a primary amine with an aldehyde yielding >C=N–R; and a 2,4-DNP derivative is the 2,4-dinitrophenylhydrazone formed by reaction of a carbonyl compound with 2,4-dinitrophenylhydrazine.
explanation: Each term describes a type of derivative of aldehydes or ketones. Their formation involves characteristic nucleophilic addition (and sometimes subsequent elimination) reactions. For instance, the formation of a cyanohydrin involves nucleophilic attack by cyanide (CN–) on the electrophilic carbonyl carbon, while acetals are formed under acidic conditions by sequential addition of alcohols and loss of water.

question_text:
Name the following compounds according to IUPAC system of nomenclature:
(i) CH₃CH(CH₃)CH₂CH₂CHO
(ii) CH₃CH₂COCH(C₂H₅)CH₂CH₂Cl
(iii) CH₃CH=CHCHO
(iv) CH₃COCH₂COCH₃
(v) CH₃CH(CH₃)CH₂C(CH₃)₂COCH₃
(vi) (CH₃)₃CCH₂COOH
(vii) OHCC₆H₄CHO-p
correct_answer: (i) 4-Methylpentanal; (ii) 3-Oxo-4-ethyl-6-chlorohexane; (iii) But-2-enal (crotonaldehyde); (iv) Pentane-2,4-dione; (v) [A complex ketone – a correct name could be 3,3-dimethyl-4-(1-methylethyl)hexan-2-one]; (vi) 3,3-Dimethylpropanoic acid; (vii) 4-Hydroxybenzaldehyde.
explanation: To name these compounds, first identify the longest chain containing the functional group. For aldehydes, numbering begins at the –CHO group; for ketones, the carbonyl gets the lowest possible number. Substituents are named and numbered in alphabetical order. For (vi), the acid is named with the –oic acid suffix, and for (vii) the hydroxy substituent is indicated at the appropriate position (para position in this case).
topic: Nomenclature of aldehydes, ketones and carboxylic acids

question_text:
Draw the structures of the following compounds:
(i) 3-Methylbutanal
(ii) p-Nitropropiophenone
(iii) p-Methylbenzaldehyde
(iv) 4-Methylpent-3-en-2-one
(v) 4-Chloropentan-2-one
(vi) 3-Bromo-4-phenylpentanoic acid
(vii) p,p'-Dihydroxybenzophenone
(viii) Hex-2-en-4-ynoic acid
correct_answer: The correct answers are the drawn skeletal structures corresponding to the names. For example, (i) 3-Methylbutanal is CH₃CH(CH₃)CH₂CHO; (ii) p-Nitropropiophenone is p-NO₂-C₆H₄COCH₂CH₃; (iii) p-Methylbenzaldehyde is p-CH₃-C₆H₄CHO; etc.
explanation: Each structure must match the IUPAC name provided. The drawing should clearly show the location of substituents such as nitro, methyl, halogen, and functional groups like the aldehyde, ketone, or carboxylic acid. This tests the ability to convert names into structural formulas.
topic: Structure and nomenclature of carbonyl compounds

question_text:
Write the IUPAC names of the following ketones and aldehydes. Wherever possible, give also common names:
(i) CH₃CO(CH₂)₄CH₃
(ii) CH₃CH₂CHBrCH₂CH(CH₃)CHO
(iii) CH₃(CH₂)₅CHO
(iv) Ph–CH=CH–CHO
(v) [Structure of Phthaldehyde]
(vi) PhCOPh
correct_answer: (i) Heptan-3-one (common name: methyl n-propyl ketone); (ii) 5-Bromo-6-methylhexanal; (iii) Octanal; (iv) Cinnamaldehyde (or 3-phenylprop-2-enal); (v) Benzene-1,2-dicarbaldehyde (commonly known as phthaldehyde); (vi) Benzophenone.
explanation: The IUPAC names are determined by identifying the longest carbon chain containing the carbonyl group and then numbering it such that the carbonyl gets the lowest possible number. For aromatic compounds, the phenyl group is used in common names where applicable.

question_text:
Draw structures of the following derivatives:
(i) The 2,4-dinitrophenylhydrazone of benzaldehyde
(ii) Cyclopropanone oxime
(iii) Acetaldehyde dimethyl acetal
(iv) The semicarbazone of cyclobutanone
(v) The ethylene ketal of hexan-3-one
(vi) The methyl hemiacetal of formaldehyde
correct_answer: The correct answers are the skeletal structures showing: (i) Benzaldehyde reacting with 2,4-DNP yields Ph–CH=N–NHC₆H₃(NO₂)₂; (ii) Cyclopropanone oxime with the C=NOH group on a cyclopropane ring; (iii) Acetaldehyde reacting with two equivalents of methanol under acid catalysis gives CH₃CH(OCH₃)₂; (iv) Cyclobutanone semicarbazone showing the –C(NH2)–NH–CO–NH2 group attached to cyclobutane; (v) Hexan-3-one with ethylene glycol forming a cyclic ketal; (vi) Formaldehyde methyl hemiacetal, CH₃O–CH(OH).
explanation: These reactions involve nucleophilic addition followed by elimination (in the case of acetal and ketal formation) or condensation (in the case of semicarbazones and hydrazones). Drawing correct structures requires knowledge of reaction mechanisms for carbonyl derivatives.

question_text:
Predict the products formed when cyclohexanecarbaldehyde reacts with the following reagents:
(i) PhMgBr then H₃O⁺
(ii) Tollens' reagent
(iii) Semicarbazide and weak acid
(iv) Excess ethanol and acid
(v) Zinc amalgam and dilute HCl
correct_answer: (i) The addition of phenylmagnesium bromide yields a secondary alcohol: 2-phenylcyclohexanol; (ii) Tollens' reagent oxidizes the aldehyde to the corresponding carboxylate, yielding cyclohexanecarboxylic acid (with silver mirror formation as a confirmation test); (iii) Reaction with semicarbazide produces the semicarbazone derivative of cyclohexanecarbaldehyde; (iv) In excess ethanol under acid catalysis, the aldehyde forms an acetal (i.e., cyclohexanecarbaldehyde diethoxy acetal); (v) Zinc amalgam with dilute HCl reduces the carbonyl group to –CH₂, producing cyclohexylmethane.
explanation: Each reagent reacts with the carbonyl group in a characteristic way. Grignard reagents add to the carbonyl carbon forming an alcohol upon workup, Tollens' reagent oxidizes aldehydes to acids, semicarbazide gives a condensation product, alcohol in acid yields acetal formation, and reduction with Zn(Hg)/HCl removes the carbonyl oxygen.

question_text:
Which of the following compounds would undergo aldol condensation, which the Cannizzaro reaction and which neither? Write the structures of the expected products of aldol condensation and Cannizzaro reaction.
(i) Methanal
(ii) 2-Methylpentanal
(iii) Benzaldehyde
(iv) Benzophenone
(v) Cyclohexanone
(vi) 1-Phenylpropanone
(vii) Phenylacetaldehyde
(viii) Butan-1-ol
(ix) 2,2-Dimethylbutanal
correct_answer: Methanal, having no α-hydrogen, undergoes the Cannizzaro reaction (yielding methanol and formate); 2-Methylpentanal and 2,2-Dimethylbutanal (which possess α-hydrogens) undergo aldol condensation; Benzaldehyde (without α-hydrogen) undergoes the Cannizzaro reaction; Benzophenone (a diaryl ketone) does not give either reaction; Cyclohexanone (with α-hydrogens) undergoes aldol condensation; 1-Phenylpropanone (α-hydrogen present) undergoes aldol condensation; Phenylacetaldehyde (with α-hydrogen) undergoes aldol condensation; Butan-1-ol does not have a carbonyl group and does not undergo either reaction.
explanation: Aldol condensation occurs only in carbonyl compounds with at least one α-hydrogen, while the Cannizzaro reaction takes place in aldehydes that lack α-hydrogens. The structures of the condensation products depend on which molecule acts as nucleophile (enolate formation) and which as electrophile. For Cannizzaro products, one molecule is reduced and one oxidized.

question_text:
How will you convert ethanal into the following compounds?
(i) Butane-1,3-diol
(ii) But-2-enal
(iii) But-2-enoic acid
correct_answer: (i) Ethanal can be converted to butane-1,3-diol via a crossed aldol condensation with formaldehyde followed by reduction and subsequent reaction sequence (or via a suitable hydroformylation and reduction process); (ii) Ethanal undergoes self-aldol condensation followed by dehydration to yield but-2-enal; (iii) But-2-enoic acid can be obtained by oxidation of but-2-enal.
explanation: Ethanol and its oxidized derivative ethanal can participate in aldol reactions. For (ii), base-catalyzed aldol condensation of ethanal produces 3-hydroxybutanal, which on dehydration gives but-2-enal. Further oxidation of the unsaturated aldehyde leads to the corresponding acid for (iii). Alternative synthetic routes may be used depending on reaction conditions.

question_text: Write structural formulas and names of four possible aldol condensation products from propanal and butanal. In each case, indicate which aldehyde acts as nucleophile and which as electrophile.
correct_answer: Possible products include: (1) Condensation of two propanal molecules to yield 2-methyl-2-pentenal (propanal as both nucleophile and electrophile); (2) Condensation of two butanal molecules giving 3-ethyl-3-nonenal; (3) Cross aldol with propanal as nucleophile and butanal as electrophile yielding 3-methyl-4-octenal; (4) Cross aldol with butanal as nucleophile and propanal as electrophile yielding 2-methyl-3-hexenal.
explanation: Aldol condensation requires one molecule to form an enolate (nucleophile) and another molecule to act as the electrophile. When two different aldehydes (propanal and butanal) are present, cross reactions yield mixed products. The structures are determined by the carbon–carbon bond formation between the α-carbon of the nucleophilic molecule and the carbonyl carbon of the electrophilic molecule.

question_text: An organic compound with the molecular formula C₉H₁₀O forms a 2,4-DNP derivative, reduces Tollens' reagent and undergoes Cannizzaro reaction. On vigorous oxidation, it gives 1,2-benzenedicarboxylic acid. Identify the compound.
correct_answer: The compound is most likely a methyl ketone with an aromatic ring – acetophenone derivative that, upon oxidation, yields phthalic acid. A plausible answer is o-methylacetophenone; however, the formation of 1,2-benzenedicarboxylic acid upon oxidation indicates that the aromatic ring carries a –CH₃CO– group that is oxidized at the side chain to yield a dicarboxylic acid. An acceptable identification is acetophenone (phenyl methyl ketone) if oxidation proceeds by cleavage and incorporation of a second –COOH group.
explanation: The positive 2,4-DNP test and reduction by Tollens’ reagent indicate a carbonyl compound, while the Cannizzaro reaction (which occurs in non-enolizable aldehydes) and oxidation to a dicarboxylic acid suggest an aromatic methyl ketone. The answer requires correlating molecular formula, reactivity tests and oxidation product.

question_text: An organic compound (A) (molecular formula C₈H₁₆O₂) was hydrolysed with dilute sulphuric acid to give a carboxylic acid (B) and an alcohol (C). Oxidation of (C) with chromic acid produced (B). (C) on dehydration gives but-1-ene. Write equations for the reactions involved.
correct_answer:
A proper answer would detail: (A) is an ester. Hydrolysis: RCOOCH₂R' + H₂O → RCOOH (B) + R'OH (C). The alcohol (C) oxidized with chromic acid gives the corresponding acid; since (C) upon dehydration yields but-1-ene, (C) must be butan-1-ol, which oxidizes to butanoic acid. Equations:
1) Ester hydrolysis: CH₃(CH₂)₂COOCH₂(CH₂)₂CH₃ + H₂O → CH₃(CH₂)₂COOH + HOCH₂(CH₂)₂CH₃.
2) Oxidation: HOCH₂(CH₂)₂CH₃ + [O] → CH₃CH₂CH₂COOH.
3) Dehydration: HOCH₂(CH₂)₂CH₃ → CH₂=CHCH₂CH₃ + H₂O.
explanation: Ester hydrolysis in acid yields a carboxylic acid and an alcohol. The fact that oxidation of the liberated alcohol gives the same acid as (B) indicates that the alcohol oxidizes fully to the acid. Dehydration of butan-1-ol gives but-1-ene. The sequence of reactions demonstrates ester hydrolysis, oxidation and dehydration.

question_text:
Arrange the following compounds in increasing order of their property as indicated:
(i) Reactivity towards HCN: Acetaldehyde, Acetone, Di‑tert‑butyl ketone, Methyl tert‑butyl ketone
(ii) Acid strength: CH₃CH₂CH(Br)COOH, CH₃CH(Br)CH₂COOH, (CH₃)₂CHCOOH, CH₃CH₂CH₂COOH
(iii) Acid strength: Benzoic acid, 4‑Nitrobenzoic acid, 3,4‑Dinitrobenzoic acid, 4‑Methoxybenzoic acid
correct_answer: (i) Increasing reactivity: Di‑tert‑butyl ketone < Methyl tert‑butyl ketone < Acetone < Acetaldehyde; (ii) Increasing acid strength: (CH₃)₂CHCOOH < CH₃CH₂CH₂COOH < CH₃CH(Br)CH₂COOH < CH₃CH₂CH(Br)COOH; (iii) Increasing acid strength: 4‑Methoxybenzoic acid < Benzoic acid < 4‑Nitrobenzoic acid < 3,4‑Dinitrobenzoic acid.
explanation: For (i), aldehydes are generally more reactive than ketones in nucleophilic addition due to less steric hindrance and reduced electron donation; bulky ketones (di‑tert‑butyl) are least reactive. For (ii) and (iii), electron-withdrawing substituents increase acid strength by stabilizing the conjugate base, while electron‑donating groups decrease it.
topic: Reactivity and acid strength of carbonyl compounds

question_text:
Give simple chemical tests to distinguish between the following pairs of compounds:
(i) Propanal and Propanone
(ii) Acetophenone and Benzophenone
(iii) Phenol and Benzoic acid
(iv) Benzoic acid and Ethyl benzoate
(v) Pentan-2-one and Pentan-3-one
(vi) Benzaldehyde and Acetophenone
(vii) Ethanal and Propanal
correct_answer: Examples of tests include: (i) Tollens’ test (aldehydes reduce Tollens’ reagent but ketones do not) distinguishes propanal (gives silver mirror) from propanone; (ii) Iodoform test – acetophenone gives a positive iodoform reaction, whereas benzophenone does not; (iii) Reaction with aqueous FeCl3 or color tests for phenols vs. benzoic acid; (iv) Saponification test distinguishes benzoic acid (forms salt) from ethyl benzoate (requires hydrolysis); (v) Careful analysis of spectral data or reactivity under enolization conditions can differentiate positional isomers; (vi) Difference in reactivity in nucleophilic addition tests; (vii) Aldol condensation under base catalysis distinguishes between ethanal and propanal based on product differences.
explanation: These tests rely on the characteristic reactions of functional groups. Aldehydes reduce Tollens’ reagent, whereas ketones generally do not; iodoform test is positive for methyl ketones and certain aldehydes; and hydrolysis/saponification can distinguish esters from carboxylic acids.

question_text:
How will you prepare the following compounds from benzene? You may use any inorganic reagent and any organic reagent having not more than one carbon atom:
(i) Methyl benzoate
(ii) m‑Nitrobenzoic acid
(iii) p‑Nitrobenzoic acid
(iv) Phenylacetic acid
(v) p‑Nitrobenzaldehyde
correct_answer: (i) Benzene can be converted to methyl benzoate via Friedel–Crafts acylation with CO and subsequent oxidation, or by side chain oxidation of toluene followed by esterification; (ii) m‑Nitrobenzoic acid can be prepared by nitration of toluene to give m‑nitrotoluene followed by oxidation; (iii) p‑Nitrobenzoic acid can be prepared in a similar manner using conditions that favor para substitution; (iv) Phenylacetic acid can be obtained from benzene via chloromethylation followed by cyanide substitution and hydrolysis; (v) p‑Nitrobenzaldehyde can be prepared by the Gatterman–Koch formylation of p‑nitrobenzene.
explanation: Benzene can be functionalized by electrophilic aromatic substitution reactions. The use of one‐carbon reagents (like CO, CH₃⁺ precursors) and subsequent oxidation/hydrolysis steps allows synthesis of various derivatives. Choice of conditions controls the regioselectivity (meta vs. para) of nitration.

question_text:
How will you bring about the following conversions in not more than two steps?
(i) Propanone to Propene
(ii) Benzoic acid to Benzaldehyde
(iii) Ethanol to 3‑Hydroxybutanal
(iv) Benzene to m‑Nitroacetophenone
(v) Benzaldehyde to Benzophenone
(vi) Bromobenzene to 1‑Phenylethanol
(vii) Benzaldehyde to 3‑Phenylpropan-1-ol
(viii) Benzaldehyde to α‑Hydroxyphenylacetic acid
(ix) Benzoic acid to m‑Nitrobenzyl alcohol
correct_answer: A proper answer would propose concise reaction sequences. For example: (i) Propanone can be converted to propene via acid-catalyzed elimination of water from the corresponding alcohol formed by reduction; (ii) Benzoic acid can be converted to benzaldehyde by reduction (e.g., via DIBAL‑H) under controlled conditions; (iii) Ethanol can be oxidized to acetaldehyde and then undergo aldol condensation to yield 3‑hydroxybutanal; (iv) Benzene can be first formylated (Gatterman-Koch) and then nitrated at the meta position to give m‑nitroacetophenone; (v) Benzaldehyde reacts with a Grignard reagent (e.g., PhMgBr) to form benzophenone upon oxidation; (vi) Bromobenzene can be converted via Grignard reaction with formaldehyde followed by acid work up to yield 1‑phenylethanol; (vii) Benzaldehyde can be homologated by aldol condensation with acetaldehyde followed by reduction; (viii) Benzaldehyde can be reacted with a cyanide source and then hydrolyzed to yield α‑hydroxyphenylacetic acid; (ix) Benzoic acid can be reduced to benzyl alcohol and then nitrated in the meta position.
explanation: Each conversion requires selection of appropriate reagents to modify the functional group in a controlled manner while avoiding side reactions. Strategies include reductions (using hydride reagents), oxidations, Grignard reactions and electrophilic aromatic substitutions.
topic: Organic synthesis and functional group interconversion

question_text:
Describe the following:
(i) Acetylation
(ii) Cannizzaro reaction
(iii) Cross aldol condensation
(iv) Decarboxylation
correct_answer: (i) Acetylation is the introduction of an acetyl (CH₃CO–) group into an organic compound, typically using acetic anhydride or acetyl chloride; (ii) The Cannizzaro reaction is a disproportionation reaction in which an aldehyde without α-hydrogens is simultaneously oxidized and reduced in the presence of a strong base, yielding a carboxylate and an alcohol; (iii) Cross aldol condensation is the reaction between two different carbonyl compounds (with at least one having α‑hydrogens) to form a β‑hydroxy aldehyde or ketone, which can then dehydrate to yield an α,β-unsaturated carbonyl compound; (iv) Decarboxylation is the loss of CO₂ from a carboxylic acid or its salt, often using heated soda lime or other conditions, to yield a hydrocarbon.
explanation: Each process is defined by its mechanism. Acetylation introduces an acyl group, the Cannizzaro reaction involves disproportionation, aldol condensation forms new C–C bonds, and decarboxylation removes a carboxyl group as carbon dioxide.
topic: Reaction mechanisms of carbonyl compounds and carboxylic acids

question_text:
Complete each synthesis by giving the missing starting material, reagent or product:
(i) [Ethylbenzene → KMnO₄, KOH, heat yields Product A] → (SOCl₂, heat) yields Product B → (Benzene, AlCl₃) yields Product C
(ii) [Phthalic acid → Reagent D yields Phthalic anhydride]
(iii) C₆H₅CHO reacting with H₂NCONHNH₂ yields Product E
(iv) [Cyclohexanone reacting with Reagent F yields Product G]
(v) [Cyclohexanecarbaldehyde reacting with [Ag(NH₃)₂]⁺ yields Product H]
(vi) [Benzaldehyde reacting with NaCN/HCl yields Product I]
(vii) C₆H₅CHO + CH₃CH₂CHO (dil. NaOH, Δ) yields Product J
(viii) CH₃COCH₂COOC₂H₅ reacting with (i) NaBH₄ (ii) H⁺ yields Product K
(ix) [Cyclohex-3-en-1-ol reacting with CrO₃ yields Product L]
(x) [Cyclopentene reacting with Reagent M yields adipaldehyde (OHC(CH₂)₄CHO)]
(xi) [2 molecules of Cyclohexanone reacting with (i) O₃ (ii) Zn-H₂O yields Product N]
correct_answer: For each synthesis, the correct reagents and intermediates must be provided. For example: (i) Ethylbenzene is oxidized to benzoic acid (Product A), which is converted to benzoyl chloride (Product B) using SOCl₂; then Friedel–Crafts acylation with benzene and AlCl₃ yields benzophenone (Product C). Similar logical sequences apply for (ii) through (xi), where standard reactions such as dehydration, oxidation, Grignard reactions, and ozonolysis are used.
explanation: This multi‐step synthesis problem requires identifying missing reactants, reagents or products based on well-known organic transformations. Each step should use the appropriate reaction condition that has been discussed in the chapter.
topic: Synthetic methods involving carbonyl compounds and carboxylic acids

question_text:
Give plausible explanation for each of the following:
(i) Cyclohexanone forms cyanohydrin in good yield but 2,2,6‑trimethylcyclohexanone does not.
(ii) There are two –NH₂ groups in semicarbazide. However, only one is involved in the formation of semicarbazones.
(iii) During the preparation of esters from a carboxylic acid and an alcohol in the presence of an acid catalyst, the water or the ester should be removed as soon as it is formed.
correct_answer: (i) 2,2,6‑Trimethylcyclohexanone is sterically hindered around the carbonyl group, which prevents effective nucleophilic attack by HCN. (ii) Although semicarbazide contains two –NH₂ groups, usually only the terminal –NH₂ (the one less involved in resonance with the adjacent carbonyl) is nucleophilic enough to condense with the carbonyl group. (iii) Removing water (or the ester) shifts the equilibrium toward ester formation by Le Chatelier’s principle, thereby driving the reaction to completion.
explanation: Steric hindrance impacts nucleophilic addition reactions. The electronic environment in semicarbazide makes one –NH₂ more reactive than the other. In esterification reactions, continuous removal of water avoids the reverse hydrolysis reaction, thus favoring ester formation.

question_text: An organic compound contains 69.77% carbon, 11.63% hydrogen and the rest oxygen. The molecular mass of the compound is 86. It does not reduce Tollens' reagent but forms an addition compound with sodium hydrogensulphite and gives a positive iodoform test. On vigorous oxidation it gives ethanoic and propanoic acid. Write the possible structure of the compound.
correct_answer: Based on the data, the compound is likely a methyl ketone with an additional methylene group between the carbonyl and an aromatic or unsaturated moiety. A plausible structure is CH₃CH₂COCH₃ (i.e., 2-butanone) but adjusting for the molecular formula C₉H₁₀O suggests an aromatic methyl ketone. Considering the oxidation products (ethanoic and propanoic acid), a possible structure is one in which a propyl group and a methyl group flank the carbonyl, such as 1-phenyl-1-propanone. However, since the oxidation gives two different acids, a structure like CH₃COCH₂CH₂Ph (where Ph is phenyl) is more likely.
explanation: The positive iodoform test indicates the presence of a CH₃CO– group. Lack of Tollens’ reactivity suggests a ketone rather than an aldehyde. The oxidation yielding two different acids indicates cleavage of a side-chain at the carbonyl. Balancing the elemental composition with a molecular mass of 86 guides the structure determination.

question_text: Although phenoxide ion has more number of resonating structures than carboxylate ion, carboxylic acid is a stronger acid than phenol. Why?
correct_answer: Carboxylate ions are more stabilized because the negative charge is equally delocalized over two oxygen atoms, which are more electronegative, whereas in phenoxide ions the charge is delocalized onto carbon atoms of the aromatic ring which are less electronegative.
explanation: The extent and effectiveness of resonance stabilization, as well as the electronegativity of the atoms over which the negative charge is delocalized, determine acid strength. In carboxylate ions, the equal distribution of the negative charge over two oxygens makes them significantly more stable than phenoxide ions.
